title: Supervised Learning Fundamentals
description: Core concepts in supervised machine learning algorithms and techniques.

cards.back: A type of machine learning where the algorithm learns from labeled training data to make predictions on new, unseen data.

cards.front: What is the difference between regression and classification?
cards.back: Regression predicts continuous numerical values (e.g., house prices), while classification predicts discrete categories (e.g., spam/not spam).
A supervised learning algorithm that models the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables using a linear equation.

cards.front: What is logistic regression used for?
cards.back: Binary classification problems. It estimates the probability of a binary outcome using a logistic function.
They split data based on feature values, creating a tree-like structure where each internal node represents a decision based on a feature.
An ensemble method that combines multiple decision trees to improve accuracy and reduce overfitting.
A supervised learning algorithm that finds the optimal hyperplane that best separates classes in the feature space.
A lazy learning algorithm that classifies new instances based on the majority vote of their k nearest neighbors in the training data.
A probabilistic classifier based on Bayes' theorem that assumes independence between features.
Combining multiple models to improve predictive performance and reduce overfitting.
When a model performs well on training data but poorly on new data, usually due to learning noise in the training set.
When a model is too simple to capture the underlying patterns in the data, performing poorly even on training data.
The balance between model complexity (variance) and simplicity (bias) - high bias leads to underfitting, high variance to overfitting.
A technique to evaluate model performance by splitting data into multiple train/test sets and averaging results.
Cross-validation where data is split into k equal parts, using each part as test set once while others are training set.
An ensemble method that builds models sequentially, each new model correcting errors of the previous ones.
Extreme Gradient Boosting - optimized gradient boosting with regularization, parallel processing, and tree pruning.
Light Gradient Boosting Machine - uses histogram-based algorithms for faster training and lower memory usage.
Categorical Boosting - handles categorical features automatically without preprocessing, uses ordered boosting.
Adaptive Boosting - adjusts weights of incorrectly classified instances to focus learning on hard examples.
Bootstrap AGGregatING - training multiple models on random subsets of data and averaging predictions.

cards.front: What is the difference between bagging and boosting?
cards.back: Bagging trains models independently in parallel; boosting trains models sequentially, each correcting previous errors.
Techniques that add penalties to the loss function to prevent overfitting by discouraging complex models.
Adds absolute value of coefficients to loss function, promotes sparsity by setting some coefficients to zero.
Adds squared value of coefficients to loss function, prevents large coefficients and reduces overfitting.
Combines L1 and L2 regularization to get benefits of both sparsity and coefficient shrinkage.
Stopping training when validation performance stops improving, preventing overfitting.

cards.front: What is dropout in neural networks?
cards.back: Regularization technique that randomly drops neurons during training to prevent co-adaptation.
Normalizes layer inputs during training to stabilize learning and allow higher learning rates.
Using knowledge from a pre-trained model on a new but related task, especially useful with limited data.

title: Unsupervised Learning
description: Key concepts in unsupervised machine learning and clustering algorithms.

cards.back: Machine learning where the algorithm learns patterns from unlabeled data without explicit supervision.
The task of grouping similar data points together based on their features, without predefined categories.
An iterative algorithm that partitions data into k clusters by minimizing the sum of squared distances between points and their cluster centroids.
A clustering method that builds a hierarchy of clusters either through agglomerative (bottom-up) or divisive (top-down) approaches.
A dimensionality reduction technique that transforms data into a new coordinate system where the greatest variances lie on the first coordinates.
It reduces the number of features while preserving important information, helping with visualization, noise reduction, and computational efficiency.
The identification of data points that deviate significantly from the normal behavior or expected patterns in the dataset.
t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding - a technique for visualizing high-dimensional data in 2D or 3D.
A probabilistic model that assumes data points are generated from a mixture of several Gaussian distributions.
A technique for determining the optimal number of clusters in K-means by plotting the sum of squared distances.
A clustering method that builds a hierarchy of clusters through agglomerative (bottom-up) or divisive (top-down) approaches.
Bottom-up hierarchical clustering that starts with individual points and merges them into clusters step by step.
Top-down hierarchical clustering that starts with all points in one cluster and splits them recursively.
Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise - groups points that are closely packed together.
Ordering Points To Identify the Clustering Structure - extends DBSCAN to find clusters of varying densities.
Probabilistic model assuming data points are generated from a mixture of several Gaussian distributions.
Iterative algorithm for finding maximum likelihood estimates in models with latent variables, used in GMM.
t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding - dimensionality reduction technique for visualizing high-dimensional data in 2D/3D.
Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection - faster dimensionality reduction alternative to t-SNE.
Linear dimensionality reduction technique that finds principal components explaining maximum variance in data.
Mathematical technique used in PCA to find principal components by decomposing the covariance matrix.
The proportion of total variance explained by each principal component in PCA.

cards.front: What is reconstruction error in PCA?
cards.back: The difference between original data and data reconstructed from principal components.
Technique for separating multivariate signals into additive subcomponents assuming independence.
Matrix factorization technique that decomposes data into non-negative factors, useful for topic modeling.
Generative probabilistic model for topic discovery in text collections.
Identifying data points that deviate significantly from normal behavior or expected patterns.
Ensemble method for anomaly detection that isolates anomalies by randomly partitioning data.
SVM variant for anomaly detection that learns a decision boundary around normal data points.
Density-based anomaly detection method that compares local density of a point to its neighbors.

title: Neural Networks & Deep Learning
description: Fundamental concepts in neural networks and deep learning architectures.

cards.back: A mathematical function that takes multiple inputs, applies weights and bias, and produces an output through an activation function.
Sigmoid, Tanh, ReLU, Leaky ReLU, Softmax. They introduce non-linearity into neural networks.
The algorithm used to train neural networks by computing gradients of the loss function and updating weights through the chain rule.
An optimization algorithm that minimizes the loss function by iteratively moving in the direction of steepest descent.

cards.front: What makes Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) special?
cards.back: They use convolutional layers to automatically learn spatial hierarchies of features, making them excellent for image processing tasks.

cards.front: When are Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) used?
cards.back: For sequential data processing like time series, natural language, where the order and context of inputs matter.

cards.front: What techniques prevent overfitting in neural networks?
cards.back: Dropout, regularization (L1/L2), early stopping, data augmentation, batch normalization.
Using a pre-trained model on a new but related task, leveraging knowledge learned from a large dataset.
A function that measures how well the model's predictions match the actual target values.

cards.front: What is overfitting in neural networks?
cards.back: When a model performs well on training data but poorly on unseen data, usually due to excessive model complexity.
The basic building block of neural networks - a single neuron that takes inputs, applies weights and bias, and produces output via activation function.
Algorithm for training neural networks by computing gradients of loss function and updating weights through chain rule.
Optimization algorithm that minimizes loss function by iteratively moving in direction of steepest descent.
Variant of gradient descent that uses single training example per iteration, making it faster but noisier.
Compromise between batch and stochastic GD - uses small batches of data for each weight update.
Adaptive Moment Estimation - combines benefits of AdaGrad and RMSProp, adapts learning rates for each parameter.
Gradually decreasing learning rate during training to allow fine-tuning of weights as training progresses.
Issue in deep networks where gradients become extremely small during backpropagation, preventing effective learning.
Opposite of vanishing gradients - gradients become extremely large, causing unstable training.
Connections that skip one or more layers in neural networks, helping with gradient flow (used in ResNet).
Residual Network - uses skip connections to solve vanishing gradient problem in very deep networks.
Densely Connected Convolutional Network - each layer receives feature maps from all preceding layers.
Layer that applies learnable filters (kernels) across input to detect local patterns and features.
Downsampling operation that reduces spatial dimensions while retaining important features.
Pooling operation that takes maximum value from each pool region, preserving prominent features.
Pooling operation that takes average value from each pool region, providing smoother downsampling.
Pooling operation that reduces entire feature map to single value per channel, reducing parameters.

cards.front: What is a recurrent neural network (RNN)?
cards.back: Neural network with loops that allows information to persist, ideal for sequential data.

cards.front: What is the vanishing gradient problem in RNNs?
cards.back: Gradients become very small when backpropagating through many time steps, making learning long-term dependencies difficult.
RNN variant with gates that control information flow, solving vanishing gradient problem for long sequences.
Forget gate, input gate, and output gate that control what information to keep, add, or output at each time step.
Simplified LSTM variant with fewer parameters - combines forget and input gates into update gate.
Mechanism that allows model to focus on relevant parts of input when producing output.
Attention mechanism where sequence elements attend to each other to compute representations.
Neural network architecture based entirely on attention mechanisms, no recurrence or convolution.
Multiple attention mechanisms running in parallel, allowing model to attend to different aspects simultaneously.
Technique to inject position information into transformer models since they have no inherent sequence awareness.
Training technique for sequence models where ground truth is used as input instead of model predictions.
Search algorithm that keeps track of k most probable sequences during decoding, better than greedy search.
Framework with generator and discriminator networks competing to produce realistic synthetic data.

title: Data Preprocessing
description: Essential data cleaning and preparation techniques for machine learning.

cards.back: The process of preparing and cleaning raw data into a format suitable for machine learning algorithms.
The process of replacing missing values with substituted values, such as mean, median, or mode.
A technique to convert categorical variables into binary vectors for machine learning algorithms.
Converting categorical labels into numerical values, typically using integers from 0 to n-1.
The process of normalizing or standardizing numerical features to bring them to a similar scale.
Transforming features to have mean = 0 and standard deviation = 1 using (x - μ) / σ.
Scaling features to a fixed range, typically [0, 1], using (x - min) / (max - min).
Identifying data points that deviate significantly from the majority of the data distribution.

cards.front: What is the interquartile range (IQR) method?
cards.back: A statistical method for outlier detection using Q3 - Q1, where outliers are points beyond 1.5 * IQR.
Dividing data into training (60-80%), validation (10-20%), and test (10-20%) sets for model development and evaluation.
Sampling method that maintains the same proportion of classes in train/test sets as in the original data.
Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique - generates synthetic examples of minority class to handle imbalanced data.
Pairs of examples from different classes that are nearest neighbors, used for removing noisy or borderline examples.
When information from outside the training set improperly influences the model, leading to overly optimistic performance.
When features that are not available at prediction time are used during training, causing data leakage.
When information that would not be available at prediction time is included in features, causing data leakage.
Techniques to artificially increase dataset size by creating modified versions of existing data.
Technique that replaces hard labels (0/1) with soft labels (e.g., 0.1/0.9) to reduce overfitting and improve calibration.
Data augmentation technique that creates new training examples by convex combinations of pairs of examples and their labels.
Regularization technique that randomly masks out square regions of input images during training.
Data augmentation that randomly selects a rectangle region in an image and erases its pixels with random values.
Normalization scales to [0,1]; standardization transforms to mean=0, std=1 using z-score.
Scaling using median and IQR instead of mean and std, making it robust to outliers.
Family of transformations (Box-Cox, Yeo-Johnson) to make data more Gaussian-like.
Transforms features to follow uniform or normal distribution using quantiles.

title: Model Evaluation Metrics
description: Understanding how to evaluate and compare machine learning models.

cards.back: The ratio of correctly predicted instances to the total instances: (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN).
The ratio of correctly predicted positive observations to the total predicted positives: TP / (TP + FP).
The ratio of correctly predicted positive observations to all actual positives: TP / (TP + FN).
The ratio of correctly predicted negative observations to all actual negatives: TN / (TN + FP).
The harmonic mean of precision and recall: 2 * (precision * recall) / (precision + recall).
The average of absolute differences between predicted and actual values: Σ|y_pred - y_true| / n.
The average of squared differences between predicted and actual values: Σ(y_pred - y_true)² / n.

cards.front: What is Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE)?
cards.back: The square root of MSE, providing error in the same units as the target variable.
The proportion of variance in the dependent variable explained by the independent variables: 1 - (SS_res / SS_tot).
A table showing the performance of a classification model with actual vs predicted values: [[TN, FP], [FN, TP]].
Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve - measures ability to distinguish between classes.
Measure of uncertainty in predictions - lower values indicate better calibrated probabilities.
Measure of accuracy of probabilistic predictions, quadratic loss between predicted probabilities and outcomes.
Statistic that measures inter-rater agreement, accounts for agreement occurring by chance.
Correlation coefficient between observed and predicted binary classifications, ranges from -1 to +1.
Accuracy metric where prediction is correct if true label is among top k predicted classes.

cards.front: What is mean absolute percentage error (MAPE)?
cards.back: Measure of prediction accuracy as percentage - average of absolute percentage errors.

cards.front: What is symmetric mean absolute percentage error (sMAPE)?
cards.back: Symmetrical version of MAPE that bounds error between 0 and 200%, treating over/under-forecasts equally.
Modified R-squared that penalizes addition of irrelevant features, better for comparing models with different numbers of features.
Measure of relative quality of statistical models, penalizes model complexity to prevent overfitting.

title: Feature Engineering
description: Techniques for creating and selecting the best features for machine learning models.

cards.back: The process of creating new features or transforming existing ones to improve model performance.
Creating new features from existing data, such as extracting date components from timestamps.
The process of selecting a subset of relevant features to reduce dimensionality and improve model performance.
Selecting features based on their correlation with the target variable or removing highly correlated features.
A greedy optimization algorithm that recursively removes the least important features based on model weights.
Creating new features by taking powers and interactions of existing features (e.g., x², x*y).
Converting continuous features into discrete bins or categories to capture non-linear relationships.
A technique to handle high-cardinality categorical features by hashing them into a fixed number of bins.
Replacing categorical values with the mean of the target variable for that category (risk of data leakage).
A measure of how much each feature contributes to the model's predictions, often from tree-based models.
Method that measures feature importance by randomly shuffling feature values and observing performance drop.
Game theory approach to explain individual predictions by computing feature contributions.

cards.front: What is LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations)?
cards.back: Technique that explains individual predictions by approximating model locally with interpretable model.
Visualization showing marginal effect of feature on predicted outcome, averaged over other features.

cards.front: What is individual conditional expectation (ICE) plots?
cards.back: Extension of PDP showing effect of feature on prediction for individual instances.
When effect of one feature depends on values of other features, requiring interaction terms.

cards.front: What is domain knowledge feature engineering?
cards.back: Creating features based on understanding of problem domain and data generation process.
Creating features from time series data like lags, rolling statistics, seasonal decompositions.
Extracting features from text like n-grams, TF-IDF, word embeddings, sentiment scores.
Extracting features from images like color histograms, texture features, edge detection.

title: Ensemble Methods
description: Advanced techniques that combine multiple models for better performance.

cards.back: Bootstrap AGGregatING - training multiple models on random subsets of data and averaging predictions.
Sequentially training models where each new model corrects the errors of the previous ones.
Training multiple models and using another model (meta-learner) to combine their predictions.
Adaptive Boosting - adjusts weights of incorrectly classified instances to focus on hard examples.
Optimizes models by minimizing the gradient of the loss function with each new model.
Extreme Gradient Boosting - optimized gradient boosting with regularization and parallel processing.
Light Gradient Boosting Machine - uses histogram-based algorithms for faster training and lower memory usage.
Categorical Boosting - handles categorical features automatically without preprocessing.
Combines predictions from multiple classifiers using majority voting (hard) or averaging probabilities (soft).
Similar to stacking but uses a simple average or weighted average instead of a meta-learner.

title: Natural Language Processing
description: Text processing, language understanding, and NLP applications.

cards.back: Breaking text into smaller units like words, phrases, or characters for processing.
Reducing words to their root form by removing suffixes (e.g., 'running' → 'run').
Reducing words to their base dictionary form using vocabulary and morphological analysis.
Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency - measures word importance in a document relative to a corpus.
Dense vector representations of words where semantically similar words have similar vectors.
Neural network-based word embedding technique using CBOW or Skip-gram architectures.
Global Vectors - word embedding technique based on co-occurrence matrix factorization.
Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers - contextual word embeddings.
Determining the emotional tone or attitude expressed in text (positive, negative, neutral).
Identifying and classifying named entities like persons, organizations, locations in text.
Assigning grammatical categories (noun, verb, adjective, etc.) to words in a sentence.
Assigning predefined categories or labels to text documents based on their content.

title: Computer Vision
description: Image processing, object detection, and visual recognition techniques.

cards.back: Assigning predefined labels or categories to entire images based on their visual content.
Identifying and locating multiple objects in an image with bounding boxes and class labels.
Assigning each pixel in an image to a class or category for detailed scene understanding.
A layer that applies learnable filters to input data to detect local patterns and features.
Downsampling operations (max pooling, average pooling) that reduce spatial dimensions.
Techniques like rotation, flipping, scaling to artificially increase dataset size and diversity.

cards.front: What is transfer learning in CV?
cards.back: Using pre-trained models (trained on ImageNet) for new vision tasks with fine-tuning.
Residual Network - uses skip connections to solve vanishing gradient problem in deep networks.
You Only Look Once - real-time object detection that predicts bounding boxes and class probabilities in one pass.
Metric for evaluating object detection: area of overlap divided by area of union of predicted and ground truth boxes.
Standard metric for object detection that averages precision across different IoU thresholds.
Algorithm that removes overlapping bounding boxes, keeping only the one with highest confidence.
Predefined bounding boxes of different sizes and aspect ratios used in object detection algorithms.
Network that proposes regions likely to contain objects, used in Faster R-CNN and similar detectors.
Technique that extracts fixed-size feature maps from regions of interest for object detection.
Extension of Faster R-CNN that adds segmentation masks to object detection and classification.
Object detection method that predicts bounding boxes and class probabilities at multiple scales in single pass.
Loss function that addresses class imbalance in object detection by down-weighting easy examples.
Task of partitioning image into multiple segments to simplify or change representation for analysis.
Convolutional network architecture for biomedical image segmentation with encoder-decoder structure.

title: Time Series Analysis
description: Techniques for analyzing and forecasting time-dependent data.

cards.back: A sequence of data points collected or recorded at regular time intervals.
When statistical properties (mean, variance, autocorrelation) remain constant over time.

cards.front: What is trend in time series?
cards.back: Long-term increase or decrease in the data over time.
Regular, predictable patterns that repeat at fixed intervals (daily, weekly, yearly).
Correlation of a time series with its own past values (lagged versions).
AutoRegressive Integrated Moving Average - statistical method for time series forecasting.
Forecasting method that gives exponentially decreasing weights to past observations.

cards.front: What is LSTM in time series?
cards.back: Long Short-Term Memory networks for modeling long-term dependencies in sequential data.
Facebook's forecasting tool for time series with multiple seasonality and trend components.

cards.front: What is cross-validation for time series?
cards.back: Rolling forecast origin validation that maintains temporal order (no random splits).

title: Reinforcement Learning
description: Learning through interaction, rewards, and optimal decision-making.

cards.back: Learning through trial and error with rewards/penalties to maximize cumulative reward.

cards.front: What is an agent in RL?
cards.back: The learner that interacts with the environment to achieve goals.

cards.front: What is an environment in RL?
cards.back: The world the agent interacts with, providing states, rewards, and accepting actions.

cards.front: What is a policy in RL?
cards.back: A strategy that maps states to actions, defining agent behavior.
Model-free RL algorithm that learns optimal action-value function through experience.
On-policy RL algorithm that learns action values based on current policy.
Balancing trying new actions (exploration) vs using known good actions (exploitation).
Exploration strategy: choose random action with probability ε, greedy action otherwise.
Combining Q-learning with deep neural networks to handle high-dimensional state spaces.
Reinforcement learning system that defeated world champion Go players.

title: Model Deployment & MLOps
description: Deploying models to production and maintaining ML systems.

cards.back: Converting trained models to formats like pickle, joblib, or ONNX for saving/loading.
Packaging ML models with dependencies in containers (Docker) for consistent deployment.
Comparing two model versions by serving them to different user groups and measuring metrics.
Tracking model performance metrics, data drift, and prediction quality in production.
Practices combining ML, DevOps, and data engineering for reliable ML systems.
Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment pipelines adapted for ML model lifecycle.
Tracking different model iterations for rollback, comparison, and reproducibility.
When input data distribution changes over time, potentially degrading model performance.
When the relationship between inputs and outputs changes, requiring model updates.
Making trained models available for inference through APIs or services.

title: Ethics & Bias in AI
description: Responsible AI development, fairness, and ethical considerations.

cards.back: When AI systems produce unfair outcomes for different demographic groups.
The ability to understand and explain how AI models make decisions.
AI systems designed to provide understandable explanations for their decisions.
Ensuring AI systems don't systematically disadvantage protected demographic groups.
Characteristics like race, gender, age, religion that should not influence decisions.
When a neutral practice disproportionately affects a protected group.
Ensuring AI systems are safe, aligned with human values, and beneficial.

cards.front: What is data privacy in AI?
cards.back: Protecting individuals' personal information and complying with privacy regulations.
General Data Protection Regulation - EU law governing data protection and privacy.
Developing AI systems that are fair, transparent, accountable, and beneficial to society.

title: Hyperparameter Tuning
description: Optimizing model hyperparameters for better performance.

cards.back: Configuration settings set before training that control the learning process.
Exhaustive search over all combinations of specified hyperparameter values.
Randomly sampling hyperparameter combinations from specified distributions.
Probabilistic approach using surrogate models to efficiently explore hyperparameter space.
Technique to evaluate model performance by splitting data into multiple train/test sets.
Stopping training when validation performance stops improving to prevent overfitting.
Hyperparameter that controls how much model weights are updated during training.
Techniques to prevent overfitting by adding penalty terms to the loss function.
Lasso regularization - adds absolute value of weights to loss, promotes sparsity.
Ridge regularization - adds squared value of weights to loss, prevents large weights.

title: Big Data & Distributed Computing
description: Handling large-scale data and distributed machine learning.

cards.back: Unified analytics engine for large-scale data processing with in-memory computing.
Apache Spark's machine learning library for distributed ML algorithms.
Framework for distributed storage (HDFS) and processing (MapReduce) of large datasets.
Programming paradigm for processing large datasets in parallel across clusters.
Training ML models across multiple machines or GPUs to handle large datasets.
Splitting data across multiple workers, each training on a subset with model synchronization.
Splitting large models across multiple devices when they don't fit in single GPU memory.
Distributed event streaming platform for handling real-time data pipelines.
Real-time processing of continuous data streams rather than batch processing.
Extract, Transform, Load - process of extracting data, transforming it, and loading into destination.

title: AutoML & Automated Machine Learning
description: Tools and techniques for automating the machine learning pipeline.

cards.back: Automated Machine Learning - tools that automate the process of applying ML to real-world problems.
Google's suite of ML products that allows developers to train high-quality models with minimal effort.
Open-source AutoML framework that automates data preprocessing, model selection, and tuning.
Tree-based Pipeline Optimization Tool - uses genetic programming to optimize ML pipelines.
Automated design of neural network architectures using search algorithms.
Tools that automatically generate, select, and transform features for ML models.
Automated process of finding the best hyperparameter configuration for a model.
Automatically choosing the best ML algorithm and configuration for a given problem.

cards.front: What are the benefits of AutoML?
cards.back: Democratizes ML, reduces time to production, handles complex pipelines, improves consistency.
May not capture domain expertise, can be expensive, limited customization, black-box nature.
Tools that automatically deploy trained models to production environments with monitoring and scaling.

title: Reinforcement Learning
description: Key concepts in reinforcement learning and decision-making.

cards.back: Learning through trial and error with rewards/penalties to maximize cumulative reward.

cards.front: What is an agent in RL?
cards.back: The learner that interacts with the environment to achieve goals.

cards.front: What is an environment in RL?
cards.back: The world the agent interacts with, providing states, rewards, and accepting actions.

cards.front: What is a policy in RL?
cards.back: A strategy that maps states to actions, defining agent behavior.
Model-free RL algorithm that learns optimal action-value functions through experience.
Balancing trying new actions (exploration) vs. using known good actions (exploitation).
Exploration strategy: choose random action with probability ε, greedy action otherwise.
Combining Q-learning with deep neural networks to handle high-dimensional state spaces.
RL approach that optimizes policies directly by computing gradients with respect to policy parameters.
Reinforcement learning system that defeated world champion Go players.

cards.front: What is Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS)?
cards.back: A search algorithm that combines Monte Carlo simulation with tree search for decision-making.

cards.front: What is value function in RL?
cards.back: A function that estimates the expected cumulative reward from a given state.
State-action value function that estimates expected cumulative reward from taking action in state.
Method that learns by updating estimates based on other learned estimates, bootstrapping.
On-policy TD control algorithm that learns Q-values using action taken by current policy.
Variant of SARSA that uses expected value over next actions instead of sampled action.
Technique to reduce overestimation bias in Q-learning by using separate networks for action selection and evaluation.
Experience replay that samples important transitions more frequently based on TD error.
Technique that relabels failed experiences as successful by changing goals, improving sample efficiency.
Training approach that presents examples in order of increasing difficulty.

title: Natural Language Processing
description: Text processing, language understanding, and NLP fundamentals.

cards.back: Breaking text into smaller units (tokens) like words, phrases, or characters for processing.
Reducing words to their root form by removing suffixes (e.g., 'running' → 'run').
Reducing words to their base dictionary form using vocabulary and morphological analysis.
Term importance in a document relative to a collection, balancing frequency with rarity.
Dense vector representations of words where semantically similar words have similar vectors.
Neural network-based word embedding technique using CBOW or Skip-gram architectures.
Global Vectors - word embedding technique based on co-occurrence matrix factorization.
Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers - contextual word embeddings.
Determining the emotional tone or attitude expressed in text (positive, negative, neutral).
Identifying and classifying named entities like persons, organizations, locations in text.
Assigning grammatical categories (noun, verb, adjective, etc.) to words in a sentence.
Assigning predefined categories or labels to text documents based on their content.

title: Computer Vision
description: Image processing, object detection, and visual recognition techniques.

cards.back: Assigning predefined labels or categories to entire images based on their visual content.
Identifying and locating multiple objects in an image with bounding boxes and class labels.
Assigning each pixel in an image to a class or category for detailed scene understanding.
A layer that applies learnable filters to input data to detect local patterns and features.
Downsampling operations (max pooling, average pooling) that reduce spatial dimensions.
Techniques like rotation, flipping, scaling to artificially increase dataset size and diversity.

cards.front: What is transfer learning in CV?
cards.back: Using pre-trained models (trained on ImageNet) for new vision tasks with fine-tuning.
Residual Network - uses skip connections to solve vanishing gradient problem in deep networks.
You Only Look Once - real-time object detection that predicts bounding boxes and class probabilities in one pass.
Metric for evaluating object detection: area of overlap divided by area of union of predicted and ground truth boxes.
Standard metric for object detection that averages precision across different IoU thresholds.

title: Big Data & Distributed ML
description: Handling large-scale data and distributed machine learning systems.

cards.back: Unified analytics engine for large-scale data processing with in-memory computing.
Apache Spark's machine learning library for distributed ML algorithms.
Framework for distributed storage (HDFS) and processing (MapReduce) of large datasets.
Programming paradigm for processing large datasets in parallel across clusters.
Training ML models across multiple machines or GPUs to handle large datasets.
Splitting data across multiple workers, each training on a subset with model synchronization.
Splitting large models across multiple devices when they don't fit in single GPU memory.
Distributed event streaming platform for handling real-time data pipelines.
Real-time processing of continuous data streams rather than batch processing.
Extract, Transform, Load - process of extracting data, transforming it, and loading into destination.
Distributed training setup with worker nodes computing gradients and parameter servers storing/synchronizing model weights.

title: AutoML & Automation
description: Tools and techniques for automating the machine learning pipeline.

cards.back: Automated Machine Learning - tools that automate the process of applying ML to real-world problems.
Google's suite of ML products that allows developers to train high-quality models with minimal effort.
Open-source AutoML framework that automates data preprocessing, model selection, and tuning.
Tree-based Pipeline Optimization Tool - uses genetic programming to optimize ML pipelines.
Automated design of neural network architectures using search algorithms.
Tools that automatically generate, select, and transform features for ML models.
Automated process of finding the best hyperparameter configuration for a model.
Automatically choosing the best ML algorithm and configuration for a given problem.
Democratizes ML, reduces time to production, improves consistency, handles complex pipelines.
May miss domain expertise, can be expensive, limited customization, black-box nature.
